results.title: The Wind in the willows
results.creator_credit: Mark Hall, Brian Cosgrove and Cosgrove-Hall Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wind in the Willows Series”.
An enchanting puppet musical that captures the beauty of the English countryside and a way of life that disappeared with the decline of the British Empire. The film features favourite characters; Rat, Mole, Badger and Toad of Toad Hall. Based on the story by Kenneth Grahame and adapted by Rosemary Anne Sisson.

results.title: The Wind from the West
results.brief_description: In northern Sweden, the exotic, nomadic Lapps, depend on reindeer herds for their livelihood. Each Spring, the Lapps seek the high uplands for reindeer feed but the very young and aged remain in the valleys. A young Nils watches the procession departing. He dozes and the Wind from the West speaks to him. He dreams that he is in the mountains with his sister, catching Brook trout, cutting willow-roots for basket-making, eating fire baked damper cakes and playing with his dog. The Wind from the West leads him to the highest mountain crag, where the Golden Eagle nests. In Lapp tradition, it is an ancient bravery test to climb to the eagle’s nest and take the bone of the white reindeer calf. For he who makes the climb, the echo, at the peak where the Lapps once made religious sacrifices, tells the size of his reindeer herd. Photography by Arne Sucksdorff. English commentary by Forrest Izard.

results.title: The Wind cannot read
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, Betty E. Box and Ralph Thomas
results.brief_description: It’s 1942, and Flight Lt. Michael Quinn (Dirk Bogarde) finds himself in Delhi to participate in a Japanese language course for interrogators of prisoners of war. His instructor is the beautiful Suzuki San (Yoko Tani), and the two fall in love and secretly marry. Tragedy befalls the newly wed couple when Michael returns to Burma and is captured and tortured by the Japanese. He is painfully reminded of the tenuous nature of their inter racial romance when he hears her voice broadcasting anti British propaganda. At first heartbroken, he vows to be reunited with his love when he discovers she is suffering from a terminal illness. Using love as inspiration, Michael vows to escape from prison and see his wife one more time before death separates them forever. Cast also includes John Fraser, Ronald Lewis, Anthony Bushell, Ken Okawa and Donald Pleasance. Based on the novel of the same name by Richard Mason.

results.title: The Wind beneath their wings
results.creator_credit: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a shy country girl, Gwen joined the Air Force when she was 18 years old and was posted at several locations around Victoria. Becoming a dressmaker after she was discharged from the army, Gwen married and lived life on a farm where she cultivated brown sheep, Shetland ponies and goats.

results.title: The Wind at work
results.creator_credit: Pat Dowling Pictures, Pat Dowling and Thomas Stanton
results.brief_description: Explains the formation and function of wind. Uses simple experiments to show the effect of warm and cold air. Shows how winds change the earths surface, and play a role in aeronautics, aquatic sports, dispersal of plant seeds and climatic conditions. Photographed by Erik Daarsted and narrated by Marx Hartman. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Wind and the river
results.brief_description: A documentary with a keen observation and a strong pictorial style which shows the life of the people of Kashmir, nestling among the Himalayas in the north-west of India. They are a hardworking people of individual charm who understand and appreciate the beauty of their land which in turn gives them courage and endurance. Without commentary.

results.title: The Wilson rescue hoist
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and Jason Ollivier
results.brief_description: An explanation of how to use the Australian designed Wilson Rescue Hoist, developed with assistance by the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority. Although designed primarily for use in ships’ holds, the Hoist can be applied to numerous other serious situations. It is simple to set up and can be carried and operated by one man. Photographer, Andrew Fraser; editor, James Steele; sound, Doug McMurdo; commentator, Paul Ricketts. Cast includes Cliff Hallet.

results.title: The Wilson Dam School
results.creator_credit: American Film Center and Tennessee Valley Authority
results.brief_description: An insight into the way in which the most successful modern education methods are put into practice. The children who attend the school at Wilson Dam, children from the homes of the Tennessee Valley, learn at school about their environment, about the River and the Valley and the Dam, and how they are controlled: about the things which affect their lives and their means of livelihood when they grow up. The school concentrates attention on the development of co-operativeness, self-reliance and understanding of the world around; parents are encouraged to visit their children at school during class hours. Photography: Russell Bushnell. Narration: John Martin.

results.title: The Willmar 8 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: GTV Productions, Julie Thompson, Mary Beth Yarrow and Lee Grant
results.brief_description: An award winning documentary which tells the story of how unequal pay, denial of promotional opportunity and lack of respect drove 8 women to form a union and begin the first bank strike in Minnesota. Suitable for upper secondary level.
